[quote]Quote:[hr]GMixer Anyway, what makes this newspaper any more "reputable" than the rest?[hr][/quote]
Where I come from, there are two classes of newspaper - the broadsheets and the tabloids. The broadsheets have a higher standard of journalistic integrity and are generally aimed at a higher reading age than the tabloids. They pride themselves on their accuracy and would not write an entirely false article. The tabloids are less accurate (some do have completely fabricated stories) and are aimed at lower reading ages (The Sun, a national tabloid, has a reading age of 6 [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-surprise.gif[/img] ) Besides, the majority of newspapers get their news from Reuters anyway.

A cock-up in the computer system that caused the woman's data not to be logged; just another government IT system gone wrong, happens all the time. The police's rather feeble response, probably caused by large workloads and little time - perfectly understandable (but not acceptable).

[hr]Grafix Also, if you have such a great distrust of the media, where do you get your news from?
[hr]I steer as far as I can from newspapers and news programs. The only things I seem to miss are stories about car accidents, random deaths, and sensationalised events which are somehow deemed important despite being only one of countless identical scenarios that take place every day (Shane Warne splits with his wife... wtf? Why should I friggin' care!?)

I prefer to keep myself informed about things that are going to improve my life or give me some sort of useful knowledge, not keep me in some sort of stale contemplation about other people's lives. Nexus and New Dawn magazines (and occasionally a couple of computer magazines, though I mostly keep myself informed about such information through friends and the Internet) are my mainstay of published reading. Then there are places like [url=http://www.red-ice.net/]red-ice.net[/url] (which I only found recently). There are a few others, but I haven't been keeping up with much news on any front for a few months so I don't remember them off the top of my head.

Before you start telling me to take this sort of reading material with a grain of salt and not to believe everything I read, let me tell you that I do my research before allowing anything to integrate into my belief system. There are some things I 'want to believe', but I'm careful not to opinionate myself about them without being sufficiently convinced.

And with that said, I send back the same words: take what you read in the mainstream media with a serving of NaCl, and realise that there are many powerplays and undercurrents going on behind the scenes and agendas with strong interests in keeping the masses ignorant of that very fact.

[hr]Grafix Otherwise, you've swayed too far into the realm of conspiracy theories and other stupid, overly paranoid ideas.
[hr]Consider back in the day when Hitler was taking power... I wonder how many people considered criticism toward Nazism 'paranoid' and 'stupid'... and look today at how many consider criticism toward Bush and his police-statesque policies similarly unfounded, and ignore the implications of things like [url=http://www.prisonplanet.com/articles/june2005/140605presidentforlife.htm]this[/url].

I find it intriguing that Clinton was nearly impeached for an affair which he came clean about a very short time afterwards, yet Bush, Blair and Howard are still in charge of three large chunks of the Western world after their blatant lies that we've put up with for almost four years.

Honestly, in ten years I hope it's the people who oppose my view saying, "See, there was nothing to worry about--you were just paranoid." But in the meantime, I place my trust in people who are interested in expanding our understanding of the world rather than keep our minds enslaved to the status quo.

[hr]Grafix OK then, tell me what is really happening.
[hr]This: billionaires want to remain rich and the 'ruling elite' (the puppeteers behind world events) want to push their agendas. Anything that threatens their money and power--industrialised use of hemp (logging, tobacco, oil industries), mass-produced alternative energy sources (oil industry) and natural therapies (pharmaceutical, sickness industries), for example--or gives the people the freedom to question their authority must be bankrupted, suppressed and crushed through any means possible.

Of course, there are many good things happening; people are waking up just as much as others are falling asleep (changing the brightness looks horrible without also changing the contrast). We're becoming more technologically and spiritually advanced by the day, possibilities that once were scarcely dreamt of are appearing every hour, and while the Unified Theory of Everything and the Meaning of Life yet elude us, we are finding answers to many things we once thought unanswerable.

That's the gist of what's happening.

[hr]Grafix Also, who do you think is more likely to brainwash you with propaganda and lies: the right-wing church or the scientists? Discuss. (I say the church - you'll probably say the scientists. As a result, this argument will continue indefinetly. Yay!)
[hr]As GMixer established, both are as bad as one anther on their own. I will not believe something just because the church says it's so, nor because science says it's so. Both have part of the truth, but their knowledge is worthless without the part that the other has, as is the case with the left- and right-wing in general.

[hr]Grafix I still think you're a bit too paranoid (some paranoia is good - it keeps us going) but you're probably winning this argument because I made several blunders and was rude on a few occasions. I'll apologize again, and maybe we can drop this rather irrelevant argument that I started.
[hr]Please, keep arguing if you feel the need. If I'm wrong about something, or if you find something I've said questionable, I want to know. Discernment can be a difficult process, especially with the volume of contradictory information scattered across the Internet, and we're all liable to form fallacious beliefs and ignore certain evidence that may be blatantly obvious to others.

Before I end this post, I want to add something to the original substance of this thread.

Recently, my cousin (the same M who was in Spleen's Saga that I posted some time ago, for what it's worth) won back custody of her son (who had been living it up with his grandmother and the rest of her rather large, yet stable family), on the basis that 'the child is better off with his mother'.

He's already been through much trauma at the hands of M's spouse (the 'dark room' used as a means of punishment, where he's sent sometimes for a whole day)... combine that with M's drug-dependencies and such, and alarm bells should start ringing. But somehow self-righteous authorities think their macro vision causes this evidence to become irrelevant.

And then there's another custody issue regarding my mother's boyfriend's son. The mother is... well, weird. For anyone who knows her in person (for the record, I don't), she should not be to given the full custody she's after, if any. Yet when interviewed or inspected (for which there is enough warning given for any fool to put up a sufficient faade) she passes with flying colours and somehow comes out sounding the more credible party.

These anecdotes are not as extreme as the one Grafix originally posted, but they're similarly abominable miscarriages of justice.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris
